document.text: UNITED STATES OF AMERICA FEDERAL POW ER COMMISSION -Southside Electric Cooperative Project No. 2748 - NOTICE OF APPLICATION OF PRELIM ARY PERMIT UNCON STRUCTED PROJECT April 3,1975 - Public notice is hereby given that application for preliminary permit has been filed under the Federal Power Act 16 U.S.C. 791a-825r by Southside Electric Cooperative of Crewe, Virginia Corres pondence to Mr. Lynwood H. Wilson, Wilson and Boswell, Attorneys,P.O. Box 45 ,Crewe, Virginia 23930 for proposed Project No. 2749, to be known as the Randolph Project, Virginia in the counties of Charlotte, Halifax, Pittsylvani- ia, Campbell, Bedford, and Appomattox, Virginia. The proposed project would operate as a pumped storage complex involving up to 13 dams and reservoirs. According to the application, the proposed Ran dolph Pumped Storage Project would consist of 1 a dam creating a reservoir on the Roanoke River about 3 miles upstream from Randolph, Vir ginia 2 several other develop ments including dams and generating stations on Hunting Creek, Wallace Creek, Cub Creek, Turnip Creek, Roanoke Creek, Falling River with Seneca-Mollys Creek, Otter River and 3 the Melrose at Melrose, Virginia, Seneca 6 miles west of Melrose, Virgin ia, and Taber 9 miles west of Melrose, Virginia sites on the Roanoke River. The application proposes several schemes of development, one of which would be 1 The Randolph reservoir would have a normal water level NWL of 380 feet and tailw ater w ater level TWL of 302 feet discharging into the existing Army Corps of Engineers J. H. Kerr Reser voir, 2 Roanoke Creek and H u n t ing Creek reservoirs would have NWLs of 410 feet and 436 feet and TWLs of 302 feet discharging into the Kerr Reservoir 3 Wallace Creek, Cub Creek, Turnip Creek, and Falling River would have NWLs of 426 feet, 440 feet, 514 feet, and 510 feet with TWLs of 380 feet discharging into Randolph Reservoir 4 Seneca and Mollys Creek would have NWLs of 650 feet and TWLs of 510 feet discharging into Falling River reservoir 5k The Seneca .- Taber developmeiit would have a NWL of 485 feet and TWL of 468 feet 6 The Melrose reservoir would have a NWL of 468 feet and TWL of 420 feet. All of the hydro-elec tric turbines would be reversi ble and would pump water to their respective upper reser

document.text: Timothy D. Notestein, son of Mr. and Mrs. John A. Notestein of Appomattox, recently com peted for and won a position on the twenty-three 23 member Youth Consulting Board of the National Rural Electric Co operative Association. The competition for this position took place during the week of June 15-19 while Timothy was participating in Washington Youth Tour activi  ties as a delegate representa tive from Southside Electric Cooperative. - After winning a position on the NRECA Youth Consulting BoarcT, Timothy, then, competed for and won a position on the ten 10 member NRECA Youth Executive Bo ard. The NRECA Youth Consult ing Board is selected each year during the Washington. Youth Tour activities. One - of its -purposes is to familiarize selected youths, with the history of rural electric

document.text: The Southside Electric Cooperative furnishes the services of two qualified Electrical Advisors. Mr. M. G . Harrison and Mr. E. E. Satterwhite are on the staff of your Cooperative to help you with your electrical problems.

text.snippet: The <mark>Southside</mark> <mark>Electric</mark> <mark>Cooperative</mark> furnishes the services of

document.text: The Southside Electric Coopera tive with main offices in Crewe, Virginia, has recently received ap proval of a 950,000.00 loan from the Rural Electrification Adminis tration to continue its expansion program and to improve the qual ity of service to its present concum- ers. This loan was made for a per iod of 35 years to be paid back ai 2 interest. The money will be used to build to 1,000 new consumers, to im prove the service to approximately 1,400 consumers in the Cooperative service area, and for substation im provement where necessary. All this money will be used in the next 18 to 24 months. The Southside Electric Coopera tive, Inc., is an electric power dis tribution system serving more than 15,000 consumers in 17 counties in Southside Virginia. The Cooperative is owned by those it serves and its entire operataion is governed by a Board of Directors who are mem bers in good standing and who are elected by the member owners of the organization. The Board mem bers receive no pay for the services they render to the organization. The Board hires a Manager to carry out the policies that they set up, and the manager in turn hire the nec essary personnel to carry on the operations of the business. Nearly ten million dollars has been borrowed by the Southside Electric Cooperative over the past 20 years to finance the building of the Largest electric Cooperative in the state of Virginia. These ,-loans were made by the R. E. A. to be paid back in 35 years at 2 in terest. Some of the first loans made to the Cooperative are in the ad vance stages of repayment and some of the recent loans are beginning to become due. However, the Co operative has met all of its oblige- toons on time and at .present is a- head of the repayment schedule.

text.snippet: been borrowed by the <mark>Southside</mark> <mark>Electric</mark> <mark>Cooperative</mark> over the past 20

document.text: The second annual 1 Appomattox County 4-H Electric Congress was held Saturday, March 16, at Appo mattox Elementary School. It is believed this is the only county congress among the 4-H Farm and Home Electric projects in the state. The Appomattox County Congress is patterned on a minia ture fashion after the State 4-H Electric Congress held in Rich mond each fall. County winners in the electric project are given schol arships to attend the State Elec tric Congress. The Appomattox County Con gress featured exhibits entered in competition by 4-H Clubs on. some phase of the electric project. This years exhibits and their awards were  Spout Spring Whiats Your Freezer. Score?  Blue ribbon, 2nd place Hesson Electricity. Works for the- Parmer Red ribbon, 3rd place. Luçky .Clover Converting Oil Lamp to Electric. Blue ribbon, 1 st place. Glendale Usés of  Portable Electric Motor. Red ribbon. Car- son From Animal Power tor Elec tricity. Wfhite ribbon. Hebron Know your Wires and Fuses. Judges for the exhibits were A. J. Lambert, Engineering Dept., V. P. I. M. G. Harrson, Southside Electric Cooperative and Miss Flora Belle Williams, Principal Ap pomattox Elementary School. The 4-H member also judged the exhibits. Those most nearly match ing the decision of the judges were Louella Martin, first Phillip Luca- do, second Eleanor Richardson, third Mary Tolley, fourth and Betsy Williams, fifth. Anotehr feature of the Congress was demonstrations by 4-H Club members. The first round of elimi nation in this contest took place in the individual clubs. Those presenting an electric demonstration at the Congress and their prizes were Phillip Luoado, Lucky Clovex Oljuib, Replacing a plug on a cord, first prize, tafyle lamp Herman Niash Jr., Glendale Club, Care and Cleaning of a Vacuum Cleaner, second prize outdoor lighting fixture Eunice Martin, Spout Spring Club Care of Irons, third place, table lamp Brenda Nash, Mrs Wilkins Club, and Linda Nash, Mrs. Wilkins Club, demonstrated Ironing and Care of Irons, placed fourth and fifth and each won an electric soldering iron. Judges for the demonstration were Dr. Aubrey Keeeee, Appo mattox School Supervisor Mrs. Virginia ailey, Home Demonstra tion Agent, Buckingham County and Mr. Jim Strickler, Virginia Rural Electrification Council, VPI. Prizes for the demonstration

document.text: The public is invited to attend a special energy program on Tuesday, Feb. 26, at 800 p.m. at Eton Baptist Church in Pamplin. The program is sponsored by the Pamplin Ruritan Club and special guest speaker will be Mr. M. B. Harrison, Service Representative of Southside Electric Cooperative.  Mr. Harrison will show a film . entitled What Time Does the Current Go Off Today The film illustrates what the future may hold for our nation in way of electric energy usage. A question and answer period, will follow the film.

text.snippet: Harrison, Service Representative of <mark>Southside</mark> <mark>Electric</mark> <mark>Cooperative</mark>.  Mr. Harrison will show

highlights.snippet: Harrison, Service Representative of <mark>Southside</mark> <mark>Electric</mark> <mark>Cooperative</mark>.  Mr. Harrison will show

document.text: The Pamplin Ruritan Club held its regular meeting last Tuesday at 7 p.m. in the Elon Baptist Church in Pamplin. After a covered dish supper the Ruritans moved to another room f which was open to the public for the 8 p.pi- program.  The program was cour tesy of the Southside Electric Cooperative. Mr. M. G. Harrison of Crewe brought the program . to Pamplin. It. consisted of a movie entitled What time will the current be on today. The movie gives a vivid picture of what can happen unless some of the Govern ment restrictions are raised so eltectric companies can construct needed power . plants. The movie indicated that there are so many different agencies involved, it appears the companies are literally tied with red tape regardless of the fuel to be used in operating a plant. Unless new facilities are built, it wont be long before there will be a situation in which power will have to be rationed between communi ties, according to the film. It takes as much as 5 years to build a plant coal, or oil

document.text: The annual meeting of the Southside Electric Cooperative to be held in Crewe this Saturday will probably be the largest in attendance ever, according to information at the organizations headquarters in Crewe. Already over 3,000 meals have been reserved for members and their friends. The program will open at 1030 a.m. with registration and lunch will be served from 1130 to 130 p.m. There will be entertainment during this period by the Southside Virginians. Shortly before the general program starts at 130 p.m., the Davis Family will entertain

document.text: The announced candidacy pf Hon. Horace H. Edwards, Mayor of Richmond,for the Democratic nom ination for Governor in the August 1949 primary, is meeting with most favorable reception. It is far too early to pick the primary win ner. Many political leaders will de sire to wait until next spring to place their support. But our guess is that Mr. Edwards will use the intervening months to great advan tage in building up popular sup port for his candidacy. He made a favorable impression in Crewe last week, where he ad dressed the annual meeting of the Southside Electric Cooperative. And the same week, following an address at Parksley, in populous Accomack County, the Eastern Shore News reported The aspir ing candidate for Virginias high est office, launched into his ad dress, espousing his governmental, economic, serial and religious be liefs and Heals in a simple unaf fected manner, yet, with a vigor, forcefulness and sincerity which apparantly made a spleldid im pression on those who were present to hear him.

document.text: The 46th Annual Membership M eeting of Southside Electric Cooperative will be held Sat., Sept. 24, st Hooper Park in Crewe, Va. Registration begins at 9 .m. Lunch will be served from 1115 until 1230 p.m., and it will include barbecued chicken prepared by Holly Farms Poultry specialists and served by the SEC Womens Advisory Committee. Each register-  ing consumer-member will be given two meal tickets and additional tickets will be available to members for their guests and children rt  2.00 each. Highlighting the business session of the Annual Meeting will be the eleciton of three persons to serve as directors for districts IV, V, and VI of the SEC service area. A special prise will be given to each registering Cooperative member, and several prises will be awarded periodically during the Annual Meeting. Local entertainment will also be featured at the Coopera tives Annual Meeting. All SEC consumer-members and friends are encouraged to attend the annual meeting.

document.text: than the original rate that was applied for to be effective Feb. 21, 1975. All wholesale rates have to be approved by the Federal Power Commission and this regulating agency ruled that the original wholesale rate that was allowed subject to refund was about 5 higher than lcould be justified by VEPCp. As a result, the Federal Power Commission approved a lower rate retroac tive to Feb. 1, 1975 and to extend thru Feb., 1977 and ordered VEPCO to refund the Cooperative all overcharges that occurred while the high rate was in effect. The 526,218.20 refund check from VEPCO was received by the Cooperative on June 26, 1976 and members received their individual refund checks from the Cooperative on or before July 26, 1976. This lower w h o l e s a l e r e m a i n iq effect thru Feb., 1977 and will be reflected in Southside Electric Cooperative consumer members electric bills. This refund emphasizes the benefits of a cooperative operation, where any money collected above the cost of operation is returned to the member owners. Mr. C. S. Hooper, Jr., M anager of Southside Electric Cooperative, stated that Infection and rate making procedures are making it extrem ely difficult for cooperatives to hold the line on the retail price of electric power but cooperative mem bers can be assured that any savings that can be affected will be passed on to the consumer members. The Manager also

document.text: Sunday dinner guests of Mrs. Marshall Martin rare Mr. and Mrs. R aj Pag and Mrs. Birdie Harvey in celebration of Mrs. Roy Pages birthday. Mrs. Marshall Martin, Mrs. Ray Page and Miss Birdie Harvey visited in the home of Mr. and lb s. Clayton Martin who was celebrating M rs. Graydon Martins birthday. Dinner guests of Mr. and Mrs. Clayton Martin Sunday were Mr. and Mrs. Graydon Martin, Mr. and Mrs. Hubbard Moore, Mr. Calvin Moore, of Nashville, Tenn. Mr. and Mrs. Victor Banton are proud parents of a new baby girl, April Dawn. Mr. Gordon Martin and son. Tommy, were Saturday guests of Mrs. Marshal Martin. Mr. M. W. Drinkard eras Sunday dinner guests of Mr. and Mrs. Giles Slade and Susanna of Lynchburg. In the afternoon Mrs. Slade and Mrs. Drinkard visited in the home of Mrs. Roger Grant. They also visited the Rev. and Mrs. T. J. Wingfield, of Thaxton. Mrs. Elsie Fairield was dinner guests of Mrs. M. W. Drinkard at Maudes Restaur ant on November 5. They were celebrating Mrs. Fairfields return from Sweden where she and her sister from New York had spent a lengthy vacation visiting friends and relatives. Mr. and Mrs. William Billy Taylor and Mr. and Mrs. M. A. Hunter visited in the home of Mr. Garland Hunter where they found him much improved. Mr. Garland Hunter and Mrs. Virginia Ragland have enjoyed the many visitors during his illness. Do come to Mt. Comfort to Spaghetti Supper on Saturday night, Nov. 19th., 5 - 7 P.M. sponsord by M. Y. F. A flea market will be held at Oakville School Saturday, Nov. 19, sponsored by U.M.W. of Mt. Comfort Church 10 a.m. to 3 p.m. Your support is solicited. Mr. Keith Martin was the supper guest of Mrs. Marshall Martin on Monday night. Mr. and Mrs. Mason Ban tan had as their dinner guests Sunday Mr. and Mrs. Vic Bantam and children, Tory and April Dawn. Miss Vickie Moore and grandparents, of Cullen, visited relatives, the Kuhls, of Culpep er. Mr. and Mrs. Floyd Hamil ton, of Newport News, spent the week end with Mr. and Mrs. Harry Lucado. Wreck Island Extension Homemakers Club Mrs. Dixie Staten was hostess to the Wreck Island Extension Homemakers Club when it met in her home on Wednesday, November 16 at 130 p.m. with nine members present. The meeting was called to or der by Mrs. Dixie Staten, club president. Devotions and prayer were led by Mrs. Frances Dyess. Speak Gently was the topic of a reading. Mrs. Dyess gave the minutes which were read and approved. Mrs. Staten led the group in repeating the Homemakers Creed. Shirley Walton announced that Christmas Open House held November 6 through 10 had an attendance of 922 guests. November 30,1978 - A special Christmas program will be held on November 30,1978 in the Ex tension Office. Meeting Room at 130 p.m. This program will be conducted by Betty Douglas, Home Economist with Southside Electric Cooperative. The topic is Santa is a Watt Watcher. Christmas Decorations and Gifts of Long Ago was the topic of the demonstration given by Mrs. Staten. She in structed members how to make Christmas tree ornaments. Mrs. Walton showed slides of Christinas decorations in Williamsburg, Va. Greeting cards were sent to the sick members. Following the meeting a toriai hour was held when the group enjoyed delicious refreshments served by the hostess. For the December meeting members will meet on Wed nesday, Dee. 6 at 11 a.m. in the home of Mrs. Dixie Staten for a covered dish lunch. Mrs. Tilden Lee, Secretary

document.text: ST. ANNS BAPTIST CHURCH Members of the Southside Electric Coqperative from 18 counties in Southside Virginia will take part in the 15th annual meeting to be held in Crewe on Saturday, July 11th, starting at 1000 oclock. More than 5,000 are expected to attend, accord ing to C, S. Hooper, Jr., the mana ger. This is the meeting each year at which the members are given a com plete report on the progress and plans of their electric cooperative and have the opportunity to seek in formation and ask questions about the organization which serves them the electricity they use on their farms and in their homes. There are more than 14,000 members of the Southside Electric Cooperative. Featured as the speaker this year will be Mr. Ancher Nelsen, the new Administrator of the Rural Electri fication Administration. He was Lieutenant-Governor of Minnesota before taking the top position in ru ral  electrification in Washington. His address will be ope of the fea tures at the afternoon session, Oon- gpessman Watkins M. Ahbitt, of Ap pomattox, representative in Congress from the Fourth Congressional Dis trict, will be a guest and will be on the morning program. Mr, Ab- bitt wU bring to the attention of the members and their guests the progress being made in Washington on subjects of vital interest to rural Virginians. His report will be most informative. Mr. Nelsen will be introduced by Mr. Harry Edmunds, also of Minne sota, and one of the pioneers in the electric cooperative field. He has been associated with Mr. Nelsen for years in the development of electric cooperatives in Minnesota. The program is to get under way at 1000 oclock with a lunch period at 1230 oclock. The afternoon program starts at 200 oclock and the entire program will be over by

document.text: Southside Electric Cooperative which has brought electricity with excellent services to th e farmers. Im delighted to say that, in my opinion, the Southside Elec tric Cooperative has very able management and conscientious and dedicated Board members. The operations have been sound and business-like. There is still much to be ac complished and I am happy at the fact that we have this rural electric system to serve us in such a progressive manner and I feel that it will meet addition al demands which no doubt will be made by the Consumer-mem bers. No Cause for Criticism Mr. Irby could see no cause for criticism of the program. He said There is no doubt but that some people criticize the rural electric program, but I am sat isfied that these Directors wel come constructive criticism. But where there are a few criticiz- si ve.

Under this As surance, this organization is committed not to discriminate against any person on the ground of race, color or national origin in its policies and practices re lating to applications for ser vice or any other policies and practices relating to treatment of beneficiaries and partici pants including rates, condi tions and extension of service, use of any of its facilities, attendance at and participation in any meetings of benficiaries and participants or the exer c ise of any rights of such bene ficiaries and participants in the conduct of the operations of this organization. Lone Gum Substation, one of 26 electric power substations owned by Southside Electric Cooperative, is used to provide electric power to more than 950 consumers in Bedford County. The resulting bullet hole caused oil in the transformer to drain out, and by 1145 p.m. on Thursday night, the transfor mer shorted out causing high voltage fuses to blow, inter rupting electric service to the 950-plus consumers in Bedford County. Electric service was, eventually, restored to these consumers around 235 a.m. on Friday morning. Because a spare transformer

document.text: Some 13,530 capital credit chocks, totaling 100,121.26, were recently mailed to persons who were members of Southside Electric Cooperative and who purchased electric service from the cooperative during the year 1964. The SEC Board of Directors approved the repayment of the 1964 capital credits because 1983 was a successful year for the cooperative. The concept of a rural electric cooperative is unique in that it is a member-owned organization, and, any- margins profits that are made during a given year are assigned back to cooperative member-owners. These margins are then paid in cash back to members as the cooperative is able to do so. Margins represent any funds collected by the cooperative that are in excess of the actual cost of the operation of the cooperative. The capital credit checks that individual SEC members will receive represents, approximately 4.94 percent of the amount of the total electric service bill that each member paid during 1964. This is the first year since 1977 that SEC has been able to make capital credit refunds, and the cooperative hopes to be able to continue making capital credit pay ments on an annual basis in the future.

Mr. Pridgen says, This is a record all employees at Southside Electric Cooperative can be proud of because all employees have participated. document.text: RANDOLPH HYDRO ELECTRIC COMPLEX MOVES AHEAD contd from page 1 dams, each step increasing the output capadty of the total project. This phase is based on a satisfactory report by the Federal Power Commission which has permitted the study period of two more years before a decision will be made to provide the work permit necessary for actual construction of these dams. The Southside Electric Coop erative has invested less than 200,088 in this development and study project. Already one Munidpality, Blackstone, has invested 2,500 in the project and other dties and towns, where electridty is purchased wholesale and then distributed retail, are eyeing the project as an investment for a source of wholesale electric energy in the future. The Board of Directors of the Southside Electric Cooperative is furnishing the present leadership for this electric generating complex, and, some time in the future, will work out a separate corporate structure to construct and continue developing the complex. Other rural electric sys tems, munidpalities like Black- stone, and even commercial power companies may become involved in the financing of this electrical generating complex, in this count down to electric independence. It is a probable 3-billion complex to be developed and constructed over the next twenty years. The construction program itself will be a great factor in the economy in Southside Virginia, Mr. South- worth added.

document.text: On Monday, December 8th from 10 a.m. to 2 p.m. the Member Service Department of Southside Electric Cooperative and Mr. Thomas W. Stone Radiological Health Specialist, Virginia Department of Health will be at Southside Electric Cooperatives Annex in Crew to help i area homemakers and th e general public with their microwave ovens. If you are concerned about the safety of your oven Mr. Stone will be set up to test your oven if you bring It to the annexThere will no charge for tSSis service. Mrs. Betty Douglass, Member Service Advisor, will have some tips on good energy management and the use and care of the microwave oven. Microwave cooking a fairly new concept of cooking is the fastest cooking method used in the home today, therefore you conserve electricity. Some people even say food taste better cooked in a microwave oven. It truly is today and tomorrows way of cooking. If you own a microwave oven, and would like to bring it in for testing, Mr. Stone will be delighted to do so. If you are thinking about purchasing a microwave oven then perhaps you will want to come in and ask questions about the use and care of the microwave oven.

Southside Electric Cooperative is serving more than 16,000 rural and urban families in 17 Southside Virginia counties bringing them elec trical service they need and deserve for better HOME LIFE. When home life becomes better in the coming years, electricity will play the important role. Southside Electric Cooperative is proud of its role in bringing better HOME LIFE to Vir ginia and is ready to meet the ever increasing needs of its members.

document.text: Notice is hereby given that Southside Electric Cooperative has filed with the State Corporation Commission of Virginia an application requesting an increase in the rates chargéd for electric service. Cooperative states in its application that the revised rates would produce additional revenues of ap proximately 812,650 or an approximate 6.29 percent increase in revenue. The Commission has suspended the effective date of these proposed increased rates and has scheduled a public hearing on the application in its Courtroom, Blanton Building, Bank and Governor Streets, Richmond, Virginia at 1000 a.m. on November 30,1978.

document.text: Mr. Safety, Ikie Pridgen, Safety Director, S.E.C., an nounced Friday, July 7th that S.E.C. employees have set a new safety record. Over 2-million man-hours, 2,065,730 to be exact, have been worked by employees at Southside Electric Cooperative without a lost-time accident. Cooperative e q u i p m e n t , trucks and cars have been driven 6,345,396 miles during this ten year period. Mr. Pridgen says, This is one of the best records of any Cooperative in the United States. He said, The employ ees have made this record because all employees are interested in an effort to work safely and because they have

document.text: Mr. C. S. Hooper, Jr., Mana ger of the Southside Electric Cooperative, has announced its construction plans for Appo mattox County for 1973. Work is in progress in the Spout Spring area converting exist ing line to increase the capacity and provide more adequate service. The estimate cost of the improvements in Appomattox County is 41,700. This is just a portion of the total of 2,300,000 to be spent

document.text: Mr. and Mrs. Melvin Garrett and Charles left Tuesday for a camping trip to Pennsylvania and New York. A speedy recovery is wished Miss Flora Belle Williams who was operated on at Va. Bapt. Hospital on Friday. The - Rocks Quartet left early Friday morning for Kingsport, Tenn. to have more records made. They returned Saturday afternoon. Congratulations to Mrs. Claudie Ranson who was 97 years old Saturday. May she have many more. Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Dickerson, Donna and Ricky were dinner guests of Mrs. Flora Dickerson and Christine Sunday. The occasion was for Samuels birthday. Mr. and Mrs. R. E. Roach attended the Southside Electric Cooperative annual meeting at Crewe Saturday. Mr. and Mrs. Toby Inge and Mr. and Mrs. Melvin Garrett and Charles returned home Saturday afternoon from their camping trip. Nancy Ranson is working in Lynchburg. A speedy recovery is wished Rhonda Ranson daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ronnie Ranson

document.text: Members of the Southside Electric Cooperative and the public in gen eral will get an opportunity to re view all phases of the progress of this organization at the 17th An nual Meeting of the membership to be held as an all-day affair at the Crewe High School stadium in Crewe on Saturday, July 16, 1955. This Annual Meeting usaully at tracts more than 6,000 of the 15,089 consumers of the Cooperative from 17 counties in Southside Vir ginia. This year as usual the planning committee will prepare the stadium for comfort regardless of weather conditions. A full report of the operations of the cooperative will be presented

document.text: man and beast. Today, not only in the cities and towns, but throughout the rural areas, electricity is cook ing the food, furnishing the lights, and producing the power for many small and large ap pliances. Relieving Drudgeries Thus, it is relieving the peo ple of much hard work and drudgery which is indeed a blessing. Our rural people have the members of the Board of Directors of Southside Electric Cooperative to thank for these blessings, Mr. Irby said. He continued To my mind, the people in the rural sections would still be using kerosene and muscle to take care of the necessary work that has to be done and, with out this rural electric system, many of us would still be doing this now. Here in Lunenburg County I do not know of anything that has contributed more to the standard of living than th e

Byrd, Jr., Virginias senior representative in the United States Senate, will be the principal speaker at the 11 a.m. session, and will be introduced by Congressman Dan Daniel. Attorney-General Andrew J. Miller, who will be introduced by C. S. Hooper, Jr., the General M anager of the Southside Electric Cooperative, will speak at the business meeting presenting an Over view of the Cooperative. . Both speakers have been frequent visitors to annual meetings of the Cooperative in past years and are well-known by most of the members of the organization. Musical entertainment will start in the morning, during the registration period prior to the official meeting of the member ship.
